CONCEPT.SN: Votes cast by persons who are absent from their usual voting district and permitted to vote by mail.
Refers to those features or characteristics of facilities, programs, services, and technologies that allow them to be used by individuals with disabilities.
Process of adopting cultural traits or social patterns of another group; also, a restructuring or blending of cultures resulting from this.
Tests used to measure knowledge, abilities, understanding, or skills acquired from academic work.
Findings by a court that a defendant should not be held responsible for the offense tried for, and may be released from custody.
The practice of vigorous action or involvement as a means of achieving political or social goals.
Basic personal care tasks used to measure functional ability in older adults.
A program that measures trends in drug use among persons arrested and booked in the United States.
Refers to adults in relationship to their parents; e.g. as caregivers of elderly or ill parents.
Provision of learning opportunites to adults in professional, vocational, personal, and social development.
Active support for and representation of an individual, group or cause.
A policy to increase opportunities for women and minorities, particularly in the context of employment and education.
Health care provided to a person after primary treatment is completed. Use also for follow-up services for treatment programs such as substance abuse treatment.
Unlawful application of physical force to another with the intention of committing an additional crime, or done with circumstances of peculiar outrage or atrocity.
Refers to the increased proportion of the older adult population, as influenced by birth and death rates, and immigration.
Overuse or misuse of alcoholic beverages. Do not confuse with "alcoholism".
Loss of interrelatedness with others; estrangement of the individual from others and/or from prevailing values, goals, and expectations of society.
United States assistance program for Latin America; begun in 1961, intended to counter the appeal of revolutionary movements and politics, particularly communism; dissolved 1973.
A disease characterized by progressive loss of memory and or mental, social, and physical competance.
Includes a range of medical care and services provided to patients without admission into a health care facility (e.g. care given in a physician's office or an outpatient clinic).
Applies to the period before the American Revolution (pre-1775).
A condition of an individual or society characterized by a breakdown or absence of norms and values or a sense of dislocation and alienation.
The southern region of the United States as it existed before the Civil War (1860).
Opposition to the British Corn Laws regulating domestic and foreign trade in grain; 1830s-1846.
System of racial segregation and political and economic discrimination against non-Europeans that operated in the Republic of South Africa from 1948 until the early 1990s.
Procedures by which a court may re-examine a case tried in a lower court and may confirm, modify, or reverse the lower court's decision.
Courts holding the authority to review and decide appeals.
Political organization consisting of Arab nations; founded 1945.
Local agencies for coordinating the delivery of public and private sector programs for older Americans.
Interdisciplinary study of a cultural, political, or geographic area.
The combined military, naval, and air forces of a nation or group or nations.
Competition between countries for superiority in quantity and quality of military weapons.
The appearance of the accused before a court where they are informed of the charges brought against them, and their plea is heard.
Official records of an individual's previous arrests and associated charges.
Administrative district of certain large cities in France.
Applies to organizations and institutes that support the arts through education, instruction, or financing (e.g. National Endowment for the Arts).
Programs and facilities providing a range of supportive care services (e.g. accomodations, meals, personal care, housekeeping, transportation, recreational activities, etc.).
The act of making the means of suicide available to a terminally ill person.
Equipment, aids, self-help devices, furniture, medical devices or communications technologies designed to aid people with disabilities.
Includes how the elderly feel toward aging, and the attitudes of others toward aging and the elderly.
The inspection of a body after death to determine the cause of death.
Procedure for releasing arrested persons, under a bond, on financial or other conditions to ensure their appearance for trial.
The difference between a nation's payments to foreign countries and its receipts from foreign countries.
The difference in value between a country's imports and exports.

Financial institutions (such as the Bank of England or the U.S. Federal Reserve System) responsible for regulating the size of a nations money supply, cost of credit, and the foreign exchange value of its currency.
Refers to skills (such as reading and writing) that form the basis of later learning.
Altering of behavior through the use of conditioning techniques.
Refers to the use of biological organisms, or processes to make or modify products.
Refers to an expressed opinion regarding the number of children a woman or couple plan to have.
U.S. federal grants given to states for use in broad program areas such as social services, community services, health, and housing.
Skilled, semi-skilled, or unskilled workers engaged in physical, rather than mental or social, work.
Refers to the state of having committed or recommitted to the Christian faith through an intensely religious experience.
A loss of trained professional personnel to another company or nation that offers greater opportunity.
Unlawful entry of or trespass within a structure, with intent to commit larceny or a felony.
Refers to a recurrent fluctuation in the total business activity of a country.
Early retirement incentives or severance benefits offered to employees as an inducement to leave.
Refers to a body of advisors to a chief of state who also serve as heads of government departments.
Refers to crimes committed by, or against, students on college or university campuses.
Sentences requiring that the convicted offender be executed by lawful authority.
A range of programs designed to assist people in selecting, planning, and pursuing their careers.
Refers to the emotional, material, and physical strain associated with providing personal care for a mentally or physically incapacitated family member.
Protection of goods and materials in transit and in storage.
Dismissal of a legal case resulting from the decision not to prosecute after the arrest.
The movement of a lawsuit or legal action through the legal system.
Number of cases handled by judges, probation and parole officers, correctional counselors, and other human services professionals at a given moment or over a specified period of time.

Financial institutions (such as the Bank of England or the U.S. Federal Reserve System) responsible for regulating the size of a nations money supply, the cost of credit, and the foreign exchange value of its currency.
A petition by which a superior court can call up for review the record of a proceeding in an inferior (lower) court.
The 1986 accident at a nuclear power plant located at Chernobyl, Ukraine (former Soviet Union).
Refers to the combined social, economic, and legal resources available for the purpose of ensuring that the individual child's basic rights and developmental needs are met and protected.
The failure of parents or caretakers to provide children with care essential for normal development.
Care of children by parents, guardians, or other primary caregivers.
Conservative Christian political organization founded 1989 by Pat Robertson; influential in the Republican Party.
Refers to the U.S. separation of religious and governing institutions.
Refers to dissatisfaction with and complaints against police, law enforcement, and the criminal justice system.
Area of study that focuses on the philosophical, political, social, and historical aspects of government and citizenship.
Plans or activities organized by civilian authorities for the protection of civilian populations and properties in times of disasters or emergencies.
Social and political conflict occurring within a country.
The body of laws dealing with the private rights of citizens, and regulating private matters as distinct from criminal, political, or military matters.
An internalized sense of belonging to a particular social class.
Refers to the percentage of crimes known to the police which the police believe have been solved.
The showing of forgiveness or leniency in the judgement of an offense or in establishing punishment.
Socioeconomic,cultural, psychological, physical, etc. characteristics of persons seeking professional services.
An interview tool used to classify according to risk assessment.
Social or activity clubs (e.g. 4-H Club, investors clubs, Boy Scouts, etc.)
Intellectual functions and mental processes by which an individual becomes aware of and expresses thoughts, perceptions, understanding, reason, judgement, etc.
Refers to the level of mental or intellectual functioning.
Refers to disturbances or reduction in mental processes related to thinking, reasoning, judgement, and memory.
Post-World War II political, military, and ideological rivalry between Western capitalist nations led by the United States, and Eastern communist nations led by the (former) Soviet Union.
Degree-granting institutions of higher education, generally limited to undergraduate bachelors degree.
Larceny, burglary, or robbery that specifically targets commercial establishments and products.
A broad term incorporating any articles of commerce; generally refers to raw or semi-processed good such as grain, agricultural produce, or precious metals.
The smallest administrative district of many countries; governed by a mayor and municipal council.
Diseases capable of being transmitted by bodily contact with an infected person or object.
Public, post-secondary institutions offering two year programs that generally include a comprehensive curriculum with transfer, occupational, general education, and adult education components.
Refers to social actions by citizen groups and individuals to develop and support programs designed to deter and control crime in the community.
Court ordered program requiring a convicted offender to perform unpaid work in the community as a supplement or an alternative to imprisonment.
Refers to changing a prison sentence or other penalty to another less severe.
The concept that a woman's and man's pay should be equal for comparable jobs.
Something given or received as payment for services, debt, loss, injury, etc.
An educational system designed to emphasize the learning and demonstration of specified knowledge, skills, etc., considered central to a particular career, activity, or task.
Congress composed of representatives of each of the eleven southern states that had seceded from the United States.
The group of eleven southern states that seceded from the United States between 1860-1861.
Oral or written declarations made by a person stating that he or she has committed a crime, or taken part in events being investigated.
Civil rights organization founded in 1942. Dedicated to the use of non-violent direct action in an effort to promote better race relations and end racial discrimination in the United States.
Applies to campaigns for elected office in either the United States Senate or the United States House of Representatives.
Applies to candidates running for office in either the United States Senate or the United States House of Representatives.
Refers to to national elections for both the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate. For state-level congressional elections see "state elections".
Applies only to national elections for the United States House of Representatives.
Applies only to national elections for the United States Senate.
Applies to hearings conducted by the U.S. House of Representatives or the U.S. Senate, or both.
Applies to votes cast by members of the United States congress.
Refusal on moral or religious grounds to bear arms in a military conflict or to serve in the armed forces.
Part of the standardized set of identification codes for metropolitan areas in the United States and Puerto Rico.
Congresses composed of representatives of the thirteen American colonies in the pre-Revolution period (pre-1750).
Education programs designed to offer specific learning opportunities for adults seeking academic or occupational development.
Drugs subject to legal control and regulation of their manufacture, distribution, sale, availability, and possession.
Records of an offenders past convictions for crimes.
Findings by a court that hold a defendant guilty and responsible for the criminal offense charged with.
British laws regulating domestic and foreign trade in grain; repealed in 1846.
Public officers whose chief function is the investigation of any death not clearly resulting from natural causes.
Refers to political and economic influence corporations have on government/political policy making.
Sentencing guidelines to set corporate fines based on characteristics and level of involvement in the offense committed.
Schemas used to categorize or classify offenders and offenses.
Educational programs provided for adults or youth in correctional institutions.
Includes short-term facilities (jails) and long-term facilities.
The various methods (such as sentencing, incarceration, parole, and probation) by which society deals with convicted offenders.
Evaluation of the financial gains and losses associated with various decisions, outcomes, or actions.
Organization composed of 40 European nations; founded in 1949 to protect democracy and human rights and promote cooperation among nations on cultural and social issues.
Activities of an intelligence service or agency engaged in thwarting subversive or intelligence-gathering efforts of a foreign power.
A sudden and decisive action in politics, resulting in a change in government illegally or by force.
Directions of a court or judge made in writing, and not included in a judgement.
Refers to a military court with jurisdiction over armed forces personnel charged with breaking military law, as well as a trial conducted by such a court.
Clandestine state-sponsored activities designed to influence and/or alter foreign governments, events, organizations, or persons.
Overall criminal justice policies within a society, country, state, etc. for controlling or reducing crime.

Includes the economic and social costs for the prevention and detection of criminal acts, the corrective treatment of offenders, the losses caused by criminal acts, and the costs incurred for protection against criminal acts.
Refers to the impact a crime has on victims (e.g. physical injuries, financial losses, psychological effects, behavioral effects).
Reporting of crimes by victims, witnesses, or law enforcement.
Refers to statistics on crimes only; excludes non-criminal and civil offenses.
A strategy for crime control combining cooperative efforts of the community, the media, and law enforcement.
Official records of a convicted offenders' arrests, charges, court actions, convictions, imprisonment, probation, and parole.
Actions taken to resolve a crisis situation, using social services, law enforcement, or counseling.
Implementation of processes designed to prevent, alleviate, or resolve crisis situations.

Major Cold War confrontation between the United States and the Soviet Union stemming from the Soviet Union's secret installation of ballistic missiles in Cuba and the subsequent US naval blockade of Cuba; 1962.
Refers to the coexistence of a number of culturally differentiated groups within a larger society.
An order calling for the withdrawal of persons from public places by a stated time.
A structured series of related courses intended to result in specific learning experiences and achievements.
Direct measurement of student performance on classroom curriculum to determine student instructional needs.
Removal of criminal penalties from acts previously defined as crimes.
Persons who are being sued in a civil action or are being prosecuted in a criminal action.
Matters of fact or law, claimed by the defendant at a court proceeding, supporting their innocense or refuting the case of the prosecution.
Processes, programs, and services emphasizing out-of-hospital treatments and/or community residence of chronic psychiatric or disabled patients.
Organic mental disorders characterized by a deterioration of intellectual functions.
A period during which business, employment, and stock market values decline severely.
Refers to a relaxing of tensions between nations; a peaceful coexistence.
Refers to the confinement of persons for any reason other than that of serving a sentence.
Use for both crime prevention and military policy. "Deterrence" refers to a strategy whereby the threat of punishment or retaliation is expected to forestall the criminal act or military assault.
Physical or mental disabilities that begin at birth or at an early age that significantly hinder or delay normal development or functioning.
Behavior departing markedly from the social, ethical, or moral norms of society.
Physical, mental, or sensory impairments that render major life activities more difficult.
False and misleading information publicly or secretly released by a government to the news media or to rival intelligence agencies.
Workers who are unemployed as a result of economic change, such as plant closings, mergers, and business failures, or changing technology.
Personal income that remains after taxes and expenses are paid.
Programs of a treatment, counseling, or mediation nature that are initiated before, or instead of criminal or juvenile adjudication; designed to aid alleged offenders.
Refers to the analysis of DNA from a sample of blood, hair, tissue, etc. for the positive identification of a perpetrator or a victim of a crime.
University-based programs of study leading to a doctoral degree.
The act of prosecuting a person a second time for the same offense; prohibited by the fifth ammendment of the U.S. Constitution.
Reduction in an organizations' workforce through layoffs and early retirement incentive packages.
Driving or operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs
Violations of drug laws which regulate the manufacture, distribution, sale, possession, and use of controlled drugs. Do not confuse with "drug related crimes".
The control of drug availability through regulation or restriction of their manufacture, distribution, sale, possession, and use.
Offenses committed to financially support drug dependency, or committed while under the influence of a controlled drug.
Determining the presence of drug traces in the body.
Refers to the sale, movement, or possession of illegal or controlled drugs.
Programs for drug dependent persons which provide a range of counseling, rehabilitation, and social services in addition to detoxification.
A family in which both spouses maintain full-time employment outside the home.
The administration and application of accepted laws and legal procedures without prejudice to all citizens.
Refers to manufactured goods such as household appliances that are not consumed in use and can be used for a period of time.
Activities and experiences intended to effect developmental changes in children from birth to grade 3 of elementary school.
The release of a person from prison prior to completion of the sentence imposed; a response to prison overcrowding.
Use of statistical and mathematical methods in the analysis of economic problems and theories.
Applies to both the activities involved in managing human and material resources in an educational setting and to the study of this process.

Process of determining and interpreting the attainment of educational objectives, for use in educational planning and policy development and the national, state, and local levels. Do not confuse with "educational testing".
Use of tests to assess the effect of educational programs and activities on students. Do not confuse with "educational assessment".
Public funds allocated to parents to pay costs of a child's education in the public or private school of their choice.
Refers to workplace efforts or programs designed to support employees with caregiving responsibilities for elderly relatives.
The buying and selling of goods and services over the Internet.
Education provided from kindergarten through grades 6, 7, or 8.
Prominent individuals exercising authority and/or influence within a larger group (e.g. business elites, political elites).
Persons who leave a native country to settle in another.
Refers to external migration; leaving one country or region to settle in another.
Programs sponsored by employers to help employees remedy personal problems affecting job performance.
A rapid spread and/or increase in the occrrence of a disease.
The branch of medicine dealing with the incidence and prevalence of disease in large populations.
Policies and practices in employment that bar discrimination on the basis of race, age, sex, religion, and physical handicap.
Amendment to the United States Constitution affirming equal rights under the law for both females and males. (Ratification is pending.)
The belief that assumes the inherent superiority of one's own ethnic group or culture.
Single currency adopted by member nations of the European Union with the exception of Denmark, Sweden, and United Kingdom.
Economic community consisting of Austria, Finland, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland; founded 1960.
For list of country members consult the "Geographic Regions and Country Names" vocabulary under "European Union".
Banking system composed of the European Central Bank and the national central banks of all European Union member states.
Withdrawing or withholding treatment or an overt act ending a patients' life for reasons of mercy.
Appraising or judging persons, organizations, or things in relation to stated objectives, standards, or criteria.
All testimony, documents, records, objects, diagrams, and expert opinion submitted to a court in an effort to prove or disprove a matter at issue.
Individuals who are no longer under required supervision by the criminal justice system.
Refers to the process whereby voters are surveyed by the media on how they voted as they leave their voting precincts.
Persons who have authority to speak due to their special training, skill, or familiarity with the subject, and who give evidence concerning some scientific, technical, or professional matter.
A network of relatives maintaining close ties with the nuclear family, often living in the same household or in close proximity.
The surrender of an alleged fugitive from justice or criminal by one state, nation, or authority to another.
Physical structures or spaces constructed, established, installed, or designated to perform particular functions or to serve particular ends.
Refers to the first and sixth ammendment rights; conflicts that arise between the right of an individual to a fair and impartial trial and the right of the public to be kept informed.
Courts holding special limited jurisdiction over domestic and family relations.

Refers to background investigations performed by government agencies and social services to evaluate the physical and psycho-social environment in which an individual is living. Do not confuse with "family history".

Refers to the tracing through time of the structure, size, membership, ethnicity, migration, cultural traditions, and socio-economic status of a family or families. Do not confuse with "family histories".
Refers to the effects of employment on family life as well as changes in work organization resulting from the increase in number of dual career families.
Legislation that sets limits on the amount of money contributed to a candidate for public office; also mandates public disclosure of campaign contributions.
U.S. agency chartered to focus all emergency preparedness and response resources at federal, state, and local levels for full range of emergencies - natural, manmade, or nuclear.
Refers to a category of crimes that fall within the jurisdiction of U.S. federal courts.
The monetary policy committee for the United States; responsible for setting federal fund rates.
Courts charged with hearing cases involving major crimes such as murder, rape, or arson.
A class of offenses of graver character than misdemeanors, usually requiring prison terms.
Provision allowing the public and press the opportunity to examine sources of income for candidates and public officials.
A single tax rate for individuals and businesses proposed by U.S. Conservatives during the 1980s and 1990s.
Refers to statistical models used to generate forecasts.
Persons visiting or living in a country they are not a citizen of.
Economic market regulated by the forces of supply and demand.
International trade free from protective tariffs and quotas.
A series of bus rides taken throughout the American South by interracial groups which ultimately ended segregation on interstate bus routes.
Use of artillery of one's own forces (military or police) that causes casualties and/or death to one's own forces.
Ability to read and write at a level necessary for participation in society.

CONCEPT.UF: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

CONCEPT.SN: Pattern of attitudes and behavior that in any society is deemed appropriate to one sex rather than the other.
A detailed account of the ancestry of an individual or group.

CONCEPT.NON-DESCRIPTOR: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

CONCEPT.SN: Refers to prescription and nonprescription drugs sold without a brand name and thus costing less than their brand name equivalent.
A branch of medicine focused on the physical processes of aging and its application in the diagnosis, care, and treatment of aging persons.
The Lower House of the German Parliament, pre-1933.
Prominent political issue within West Germany following the division of Germany in 1949 to the reunification in 1990.
Study of the aging; encompasses social, biological, psychological, and environmental contexts.
Residential areas, usually within cities, in which members of a particular racial or cultural group live, primarily because of social, economic, or legal factors. Do not confuse with "slums".
Gradual increase in the earth's average temperature that causes corresponding changes in climate.
Refers to the suspension or stoppage of government operations.
A school, usually a division of a university, offering courses leading to degrees beyond the bachelors degree.
Persons pursuing studies leading to degrees beyond the bachelors degree.
Persons who have completed requirements of an educational program and have been awarded a degree, diploma, or certificate.
A group of persons selected, sworn, and authorized by law to evaluate evidence in order to decide whether or not to indict.
Funds given by a foundation, government, or other organization, designated for a specific purpose.
Gross National Product excluding payments on foreign investments.
The total monetary value of all goods and services produced in a country during one year.
Citizen organization formed to patrol neighborhoods in an effort to thwart or prevent crime.
Legal document requiring a person be brought before a judge or court to determine whether detention or imprisonment is lawful.

Threats or acts of violence directed toward racial, ethnic, or religious groups based on age, sex, or disability, or those who are perceived to adopt lifestyles or beliefs that are unacceptable to some segment of society.
Comprehensive child-focused program with the overall goal of increasing the school readiness of young children in low income families.
Individuals' attitudes toward health practices and their own health.
Lifestyles and practices that have an impact on health.
Refers to the actual costs of providing health care services (e.g. costs of procedures, medications, etc.). Do not confuse with "health expenditures".
Educational activities designed to promote understanding and behavior consistent with health needs of the individual and the community.
The amounts spent by individuals, groups, nations, or organizations for total health care and its associated components. Do not confuse with "health care costs".
State of health of an individual, group, or population.
A session in which testimony and arguments are presented before a judge or appointed body having decision-making authority.
Refers to out-of-court statements made by a witness or potential witness during the course of a court trial.
Adult education programs designed to prepare individuals for taking the tests leading to a high school equivalency certificate.
All education beyond the secondary education level leading to a formal degree.
Use this term to designate cultural/ethnic origins. Do not confuse with "Hispanic or Latino Americans" (which implies citizenship).
Health and personal care services delivered to the elderly in their homes.
Paid workers providing personal and health care to older adults in their home. Do not confuse with "caregivers", who are unpaid and often family members.
Skilled and supportive services designed to maintain or restore health, or to minimize effects of illness or disability for aged, disabled, or sick individuals in their own home.
Education provided in the home rather than in the traditional school environment.
Unreasoning fear of or antipathy toward homosexuals and homosexuality.
Includes the hospice concept as well as facilities and programs for meeting the needs of the terminally ill and their families.
A home incarceration program where the offender is often monitored by electronic equipment.
Refers to condition of kitchen, roof, windows, plumbing, heating/cooling units, presence and condition of basement, garage, etc.
Refers to moving to a country of which one is not a native.
The policy of extending the rule or authority of one nation over foreign countries, often for economic gain.
Capability of an individual to be self-governing and not dependent on others for care, well-being, or livelihood.
Factors that directly or indirectly affect the condition of an individual, group, entity, or event by altering the situation or determining a result.
Ability to discover, access, evaluate, and use information from a variety of sources and in a variety of formats.
Permission given by a person for medical treatment or intervention after being provided the information necessary to make the decision.
Toxic vapors inhaled for the purpose of altering the psychic or physical state.
A judicial process or order requiring a person to refrain from doing a particular thing.
Process of categorizing prison inmates according to offense, attitude, behavior, etc., to assigning them to appropriate programs, or segregate them from other segments of the prison population.
Rehabilitation programs of an educational, counseling, vocational, recreational, or health care nature, designed to address inmate needs.
The introduction of new ideas, methods, tools, etc.
Process involving the transfer, spread, and adoption of new ideas, methods, tools, etc.
A legal defense claiming the defendant is not criminally responsible due to mental incapacity at the time the criminal offense was committed.
Placement or confinement of persons to a psychiatric hospital or similar facility. Do not confuse with "institutional care".
Process by which knowledge, attitudes, or skills are deliberately conveyed. Use "teaching (occupation)" when referring to the teaching profession.
Refers to the gathering, analysis, and use of secret information about an enemy or potential enemy.
Tensions, stresses, disagreements between the generations, in the family as well as in society.
International organizations comprised of representative from two or more governments or from two levels of government.
Marriage between different racial, religious, and social group members.
The interpersonal sharing of opinions, interests, and feelings between two or more people; can be verbal or nonverbal (i.e. written communications).
Activity undertaken to prevent or cope with social problems, usually by local or governmental welfare agencies.
Refers to partners in a dating, cohabiting, or marital relationship.
Refers to the mid-1980s sale of American arms to Iran and the secret diversion of funds from that sale to aid the rebel forces (Contras) in Nicaragua.
Refers to the 1979 seizure of the American Embassy in Tehran by Iranian students and the holding of 52 Americans as hostages. Hostages were released in 1981.
Use for persons who have been sentenced for less than one year and incarcerated in jails (short-term correctional facilties); do not confuse with "prison inmates"
Short-term correctional facilities, for persons sentenced to less than one year.
Applies to both the appointment and the election of judges.
A public officer authorized to hear and decide cases in a court of law.
The active progressive participation by a court judge in judicial administration and application of law or precedent.
Refers to the process followed by judges when deciding a case.
If possible, use a more specific term or terms from the list below.
Reviews by courts of decisions by other branches of government, including review of statutes, administrative acts, official acts, and court decisions, to examine their constitutionality.
A group of persons selected by law and sworn to examine the evidence in a legal case and render a verdict to a court.
Official or legal predetermined division of a larger whole within which lawful authority may be exercised.
Directions given to a jury concerning the rules and principles of law applicable to the case before them.
Courts holding special jurisdiction over juvenile offenders and neglected children.
Persons committing offenses while under a statutorily defined age limit, generally set between 16-21 years.
Persons under the age of majority; upper age limit may vary with jurisdiction, but is usually set between 16-21 years.
Refers to the extent of knowledge attained by an individual.
Refers to relations between labor and corporate management.
Refers to the formal educational process of learning another language.
Process of acquiring knowledge, attitudes, or skills from study, instruction, or experience.
Provision of publicly funded legal services for those unable to afford them.
Application to a higher court for review of the outcome of court case.
A law or body of laws that have been officially enacted.
A deliberative body of persons who are empowered to make, change, or repeal the laws of a country or state.
Refers to the governmental investigation of an affair between White House intern Monica Lewinsky and President Bill Clinton, 1998-1999.
Series of significant physical and emotional periods through which an individual passes during a lifetime.
Memorable, unusual, or significant events in a persons' life (e.g. birth of a child, retirement, death of a spouse, etc.).
Refers to an individuals' account of life experiences.
Medical technology and machines used to support and sustain life by artificially substituting essential body functions such as breathing.
The way of life that characterizes a specific individual or group.
Laws regulating the manufacture, sale, distribution, and possession of alcoholic beverages.
Illegally acquiring, manufacturing, selling, distributing, transporting, or possessing alcoholic beverages.
Refers to the ability to read and write; to communicate using written symbols.

Legal documents allowing individuals to transfer ownership of money or property to trusts with instructions for the trusts' management and distribution upon the individuals' disability or death. Do not confuse with "living wills".
Document in which a person stipulates that no extraordinary measures are to be used to prolong his or her life in the event of terminal illness. Do not confuse with "living trusts".
Unlawfully lending money at a rate of interest higher than the maximum rate set by law.
Efforts made to influence legislators or other public officials to vote or act in favor of a special interest.
Persons who try to influence legislation or administrative decisions on behalf of a special interest.
Includes care programs both in and outside of institutions.
The Treaty of the European Union; signed in Maastricht, the Netherlands, 1992.
The study of large economic systems (such as a nation) comprised of different sectors.
Schools designed to draw students on a voluntary basis from all parts of a school district by offering courses not available through the regular school curriculum.
Specific terms of imprisonment, automatically applied upon conviction, not subject to modification by a judge.
The unlawful killing of a human being without malice aforethought.
The degree of contentment one feels with married life.

A system of economic organization that operates according to the laws of supply and demand, with minimal government regulation, and control of production and distribution in the hands of private persons or corporations.
Foreign aid program designed to foster economic recovery and sociopolitical stability in European countries after World War II.
Governing of civilian population by the military; may supercede ordinary law and civil courts.
University-based programs of study leading to a masters degree.

Refers to the highest level of security precautions used for persons convicted of serious crimes or who have a history of violence; also can refer to situations or events that require exceptional security measures.
Intervention between conflicting parties to promote reconciliation, settlement, or compromise.
U.S. government program of medical insurance for persons with very low incomes. Do not confuse with "medicare".
Refers to both the determination of an individual's health and need for treatment and to judging the efficacy of a medical program or procedure.
U.S. government program of medical insurance for aged or disabled persons. Do not confuse with "medicaid".
Period in Japanese political history, lasting from 1868 to 1912.
Refers to grave or disabling failure of adjustment, whether temporary or chronic.
Treatment involving drug substitution therapy that replaces opiate addiction with methadone dependence.
Refers to the standardized set of identification codes for metropolitan areas of the United States and Puerto Rico.
Part of the standardized set of identification codes for metropolitan areas in the United States and Puerto Rico.
The branch of economics dealing with particular aspects of an economy (such as an industry, a household, or a sector).
For more specific geographic terms, consult the "Geographic Regions and Country Names" vocabulary list.
Schools encompassing grades 5 or 6 through grade 8.
Crimes committed on a military base or by military personnel.
The selection of persons for compulsory military service.
Soldiers who perform police duties within the armed forces.
Official records of an individual's military experience and career.
United States Supreme Court ruling requiring law enforcement officers to warn persons taken into custody that they have the right to remain silent and are entitled to legal counsel.
Includes criminal offenses committed by government officals or employees in the performance of their duties.
A court trial terminated without conclusion either because of prejudicial error in the proceedings or because a jury cannot agree on a verdict.
U.S. federal grant program for renewal of urban areas. Now consolidated into community development block grants.
U.S. conservative Christian political action group founded in 1979 by evangelist Rev. Jerry Falwell; influential in the Republican Party. Dissolved 1989.
The proportion or incidence of a specific disease within a geographic locality.
Refers to the relative frequency of deaths within a specific population.
Courts whose territorial authority is confined to the city or community; municipal courts exist in the judicial organization of some U.S. states.
A city, town, village, or borough possessing corporate existence and its own local government.
The unlawful killing of another person done with deliberation or premeditation.

CONCEPT.UF: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

CONCEPT.SN: Trade agreement between United States, Mexico, and Canada.

CONCEPT.NON-DESCRIPTOR: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People

CONCEPT.SN: Criminal victimization surveys undertaken by the United States Bureau of the Census.
A militia force employed by the state for law enforcement and the suppression of civil disorder; also may be called into federal service as part of the armed forces.

Voluntary nonpartisan community service agency, founded in 1910, whose goal is to help end racial segregation and discrimination in the United States, and to help economically and socially disadvantaged groups.
An international multi-nation organization formed in 1949 for the purpose of collective defense.
Process of identifying needs and establishing priorities among them.
Part of the standardized set of identification codes for metropolitan areas in the United States and Puerto Rico.
Refers to President Gerald Ford's granting of a full pardon to ex-President Richard Nixon in 1974.
International nonprofit organizations created and financially supported independent of government, working primarily in developing nations.
Refers to paraprofessional school personnel who assist professional staff in noninstructional areas.
Institutions providing full-time nursing and personal care.

CONCEPT.USE: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

CONCEPT.SN: Categorization of offenders according to offense, criminal history, IQ, etc., to assign them to appropriate programs or treatment.
Profiles based on characteristics, attitudes, motivations, and behavioral traits of offenders involved in specific types of crime.
Process of categorizing offenses according to specific criteria.
Refers to the terrorist attack in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, U.S., April 19, 1995.
Legislation enacted for the provision of social and health-related services to older Americans.
Refers to workers aged 40 and older, protected from employment discrimination under the "Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA)".

CONCEPT.DESCRIPTOR: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

CONCEPT.SN: Political organization consisting of independent African states; founded 1963.
Political organization consisting of Canada, Mexico, United States, and countries from South America and Central America; founded 1948.
Efforts to increase the availability and utilization of services especially through direct intervention and interaction with the target communities.
Political umbrella organization composed of several Palestinian groups.
Governing body of the proposed independent state of Palestine; established 1994 as part of the peace agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.
The conditional release of a person from prison prior to the end of the sentence imposed.
Refers to a change in political party membership or affiliation by an individual.
A social psychological attachment to a political party.
Rights of patients to be informed about their condition and prognosis and to make decisions concerning their treatment.
Refers to the U.S. Patriot Act, enacted after the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, which broadens law enforcement's use of surveillance techniques and tools.
Refers to the Japanese bombing of the US Pacific fleet in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, 1942; precipitated the US entrance into World War II.
Evaluation of student achievement and learning that requires direct demonstration of knowledge and skills.
Conflict between Iraq and the United States and its' allies to expel Iraq from Kuwait (1991).
Attributes of individual identity; the sum total of the physical, mental, emotional, and social characteristics of an individual.
Evaluation to determine patterns of personal traits that characterize an individual's motivation, temperment, or behavior.
Assessing employee value, competance, productivity, etc. according to established criteria or standards.
Refers to restrictions placed on physician selection implemented by some health insurers.
An agreement in criminal proceedings in which a guilty plea is obtained from the accused in exchange for a reduction in the charges.
A defendants' answer to a legal declaration or charge against them.
Individuals in a police apprenticeship program who are below the minimum entry age for appointment to the police force.
Refers to police officer deaths in the line of duty.
Physical equipment and resources used in the performance of police functions.
All official records collected, organized, and maintained by police departments.
Actions taken by police officers to direct non-crime-related requests for assistance to other agencies within or outside the criminal justice system.
Non-crime-related police services within the community.
A totalitarian state or country in which a national police force, especially secret police, suppresses any act that conflicts with government policy.
Ability of political action to produce the desired result or effect.

Refers to the power or control exercised by an individual, group, or set of symbols to impact the perceptions and beliefs of the wider population, and to facilitate the actions of governmental bodies and political institutions. Do not confuse with "political influences".

Refers to events, ideologies, learning experiences, etc. in a variety of sociocultural contexts which impact and define an individual's political views, attitudes, and behavior. Do not confuse with "political influence".
Refers to process by which political norms are transmitted through various social agents, such as schools, parents, peer groups, mass media, etc.
Refers to social, economic, and political affairs within and between nations worldwide following the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the re-unification of Germany (1990).
Acute, chronic or delayed reactions to traumatic events that are outside the normal range of human experience, such as military combat, assault, or natural disasters.
Refers to social, economic, and political affairs within and between nations worldwide following the end of World War II (1945).
All education and learning activities beyond the secondary (grades 7, 8, or 9 through 12) level.
Process of foretelling future events, conditions, outcomes, or trends on the basis of current information.
Programs designed to phase prison inmates into community life, and provide assistance as needed.
Refers to public debates between candidates running for president.
Reputation, influence, high esteem, etc. accorded an individual, group, institution, or role/occupation.
Procedure allowing an accused person to avoid detention or imprisonment before and during a trial.
Health and medical services received at the first point of entry into the health care delivery system.
Part of the standardized set of identification codes for metropolitan areas in the United States and Puerto Rico.
Adjustment(s) made by the individual to the prison environment.
Use for persons who have been sentenced for serious crimes and are incarcerated in long-term correctional facilities; do not confuse with "jail inmates".
Refers to the transfer of government assets and services to the private sector.
Reasonable ground for a belief that the accused was guilty of the crime.
Criminal sentence in which the offender is allowed to remain out of prison under the supervision of a probation officer appointed by the court.
Judging the feasibility, efficacy, value, etc. of a program in relation to stated objectives, standards, or criteria.
Refers to the historical period of time when alcohol manufacture, sale, and use was against the law throughout the United States.
Proposition to reduce property taxes by more than half, voted into effect in California 1978.
Exemption from prosecution in return for testimony or evidence bearing on a court case.
A country's efforts to protect domestic industries from foreign competition through the imposition of import tariffs or quotas.
Confinement of individuals for their own safety or for the safety of the public.
Evaluation of an individual's mental health or condition.
Refers to the study and practice of management of governmental functions and agencies.
Lawyers designated to represent indigent defendants in criminal cases at public expense.
Housing that is owned and operated by a local public agency that is funded by state or federal agencies.
Confinement, restriction of activities, infliction of pain, asset forfeiture, or other measures taken for retribution, to force compliance, or invoke behavioral change.
A system for verifying and maintaining a desired level of quality in a product or process, using techniques such as inspection and regulation.
A supply-side economic program consisting of tax cuts and non-defense budget cuts instituted by republican President Ronald Reagan in the early 1980s.
A period of economic decline when production, employment, and earnings fall below normal levels.
Recurrence of or relapse into criminal or delinquent behavior.
Period following the American Civil War during which the states that had seceded were reorganized as part of the Union; 1865-1877.
Process by which existing congressional districts are re-divided for political and electoral purposes.
The practice of referring measures proposed or passed by a legislative body to the vote of the electorate for approval or rejection.
Instruction in religion at any educational level, not leading to theology degree.
A blending of evangelical protestantism and conservative politics.
Refers to the voluntary or forced removal of an individual or group and their settlement in a new location.
Pressure or forcible retraint exercised by political or military forces.
Short term relief care designed to temporarily substitute for full-time caregivers in or outside the home.
Criminal justice programs under which an offender is required to repay the victim or society in money or services, as a condition of the sentence.

Involves processes and programs whereby an offender is required to provide restoration or compensation to the victim(s) or society, in the form of money or services,as a condition of the sentence or of probation.
A judicial order to forbid a particular act or forbid contact with specific individuals.
Adjustment(s) made by the individual to retirement.
Sweeping changes associated with the downfall and replacement of a previously stable social/political order.
Right of patients to refuse life sustaining medical procedures, or to have those procedures withdrawn.
Biological or social factors that predispose individuals to the development of physical, emotional, mental, or behavioral disorders.
Methods dealing with possible loss, injury, disadvantage, or destruction.
The forcible taking of property in the possession of another by use of violence or threat of violence.
Concerns the roll call votes and voting patterns of legislative bodies.
Mechanisms of social control that impose rewards or punishments; used to encourage conformity to specified standards.
A group of mental disorders characterized by varying combinations of symptoms such as bizarre behavior, delusions, hallucinations, incoherence, and catatonia.
Transporting students for the purpose of school desegregation.
Parental option to select a particular school within a district or choosing public, private, religious, charter schools, often by means of educational vouchers.
Individual or group prayer in a public school setting.
Refers to the physical, emotional, social, and cognitive maturity required for learning in a school setting.
Administrators at the district, city, or state level who direct and coordinate activities of school systems in accordance with school board standards.
Education provided for grade 7, 8, or 9, through grade 12.
A police force that operates secretly, especially to suppress dissent against the government.
Separation of a race, class, or ethnic group by either voluntary or enforced means.
Non-medical term for physical and mental deterioration associated with old age.
Pronouncement by the court of the penalty to be imposed upon convicted offenders.
Refers to efforts made by culturally or ideologically distinct segments of a nation to secede and become an independent governmental and national entity.
Refers to the terrorist attacks on New York City and Washington, DC in 2001.
Requirement that released sex offenders register with police or other agency.
Attitudes or behavior based on traditional stereotypes of gender roles.
Programs in which offenders undergo a regimen of strict discipline, marching and drilling, physical exercise, and hard labor usually within prison walls, but segregated from regular inmates.

Refers primarily to efforts on behalf of U.S. slave descendants to procure a government apology and financial compensation for the enslavement of their ancestors. Can be applied to other national/cultural contexts as well.
Residential areas, usually within cities, characterized by deteriorated buildings, high population density, poverty, and generally poor living conditions. Do not confuse with "ghettos".
Stratified levels in human populations defined by wealth, privilege, modes of labor, way of life, and other sociocultural factors.
Perceived or actual social separation between individuals or groups, as measured by the degree of prejudice or sympathetic understanding between them.
Individuals' association with and sense of belonging to socially defined groups.
Characteristics used as measures of the quality of life of individuals and social groups.
Processes by which social groups merge with one another; also, processes by which individuals come to identify themselves with sociocultural groups.
Collective activities that emerge in the context of perceived social injustice.
A series of communication linkages relating groups, organizations, or persons in social situations; can be interpersonal, economic, political, action-based, or role-based links.

Refers to processes, services, and programs provided through the criminal justice system and social services agencies that are designed to re-integrate individuals into society. Do not confuse with "social integration".
Emotional, physical, or spiritual assistance provided by individuals, groups, organizations, and institutions to persons in need.
Process of acquiring social roles and identity, and learning to function within a group, according to group values and behavioral rules.
Refers to money contributed to a political party or candidate that is not subject to Federal regulations.
Confinement of a prisoner in a cell or other place in isolation from others.
Former military alliance consisting of Australia, France, New Zealand, Pakistan, Philippines, Thailand, United Kingdom, and United States; founded 1954, dissolved 1977.
Educational programs and services designed for individuals with special needs (intellectual, emotional, or physical).
Refers to someone who intentionally and repeatedly follows, harasses, and/or intimidates another person with the intent to place that person in reasonable fear of bodily injury or death.
To intentionally and repeatedly follow, harass, and/or intimidate another person.
Refers to educational tests for which the content, methods for administering the tests, and evaluating the results have been established and followed in a uniform manner.
Rules or criteria by which levels of adequacy, acceptability, quality, or value are assessed.
Applies to U.S. state-level House of Representatives and/or state-level Senate.
Use this term when referring to statistics as a field of study. For collections of statistics use "statistical data" or a more specific term such as "crime statistics".
Violations of law that are specific to juveniles and not considered as crimes if committed by adults.
A family composed of a parent, a step-parent and a child or children from a previous marriage.
A simplified and standardized conception or image of a person, groups, condition, etc., held in common by members of a group.
Refers to both the "SALT talks" and the "SALT Treaty" between the United States and the (former) Soviet Union.
Refers to the U.S. government-sponsored program (in the 1980s) to research and develop a space-based missile defense system.
Refers to activities carried out with the intention to undermine and/or overthrow an existing organization, institution, or government.
Federal financial assistance program that guarentees minimum income to low-income aged, blind, and disabled persons.
Professional services designed to enable individuals to remain independent in they're own homes for as long as possible; includes services provided by assisted living facilities for residents.
Applies to both the U.S. Supreme Court and the state Supreme Courts.
Applies to both the U.S. Supreme Court and the state Supreme Courts.
Witness or victim description of the physical characteristics of an alleged offender, or recognition of the suspect, as in a police lineup.
Postponement of sentences imposed on convicted offenders.
Period in Japanese political history, lasting from 1912 to 1926.
Syndrome attributed to stressful occupational conditions of the teaching profession.
Assessing teacher performance according to established criteria.
Refers to the profession of teaching, its occupational conditions and attributes. Use "instruction" when referring to the teaching process.
The 1979 accident at a nuclear power plant located on Three Mile Island, Pennsylvania.
Allocation, expenditure, or managment of work or leisure time by individuals or groups.
Indigenous practitioners who use cultural knowledge, beliefs, and methods in the identification and treatment of illness.
Refers to cultural knowledge and methods of healing used by indigenous practitioners in traditional societies including Native Americans, as well as ethnic populations in industrialized countries.
Client-patient oriented activities in medical and psychiatric contexts. Select a more specific term from the list below.
The degree to which a person participates in a structured treatment program and follows the directions or instructions for the program.
Includes financial, physical, emotional, and social costs of treatment.
Measurements of a variable taken over time in order to indicate a direction of change.
Refers to reliance on the integrity, strength, ability, surety, etc. of a person, group, institution, idea, or thing.
Funds or property held by one person and designated for the benefit of another.
Criminal justice statistical reporting by state and local agencies in conformance with national reporting standards. In the United States this is based on the FBI Uniform Crime Reports.
The army representing the northern non-slave states against the secessionist southern (Confederacy) states during the American Civil War.
Use is limited to the national-level United States House of Representatives. For the equivalent body at the state level use "state legislatures".
Use is limited to the national-level United States Senate. For the equivalent body at the state level use "state legislatures"
For supreme courts of the various U.S. states use the term "state supreme courts"; for foreign supreme courts use "foreign courts".
Degree-granting institution of higher education; generally includes a liberal arts undergraduate college, a graduate school, and one or more undergraduate and graduate professional schools.
Any means by which persons travel or goods and materials are conveyed
Refers to a judge's decision to reverse or reduce the verdict supplied by a jury.
The findings of a jury in a matter submitted to their judgement by the courts.
Refers to the rights of victims during any process of the criminal justice system.
Includes prosecutory, community, or police efforts to alleviate the effects of crime or criminal investigations through provision of counseling, medical aid, and other services.
Process and activities in which persons assume the authority of the law, alleging the failure of existing law enforcement agencies.
Formal instruction and preparation for skilled, technical, or paraprofessional occupations.
Process of developing, restoring, or preserving the ability to engage in suitable employment through such services as diagnosis, guidance counseling, education, training, and placement.
Refers to the total number of votes received by a candidate or political party.
Compensation paid by a defeated nation to the victor for damages and loss suffered during a war.
Former Soviet bloc military alliance, represented Communist counterpart to NATO; founded 1955, dissolved 1991.
Refers to a series of political scandals involving the Nixon Administration during the 1972 presidential campaign that culminated in the resignation of President Richard Nixon.
Violations of state, local, or Federal laws that relate specifically to possessing, carrying, licensing, firing, selling, or using weapons.
Assistance for persons who are unable to meet their needs through their own income.
Crimes committed by persons of high professional and social status, usually related to their employment and generally involving fraud, embezzlement, and financial misdealing.
Non-manual salaried workers engaged in clerical, administrative, sales, and technical occupations.
Refers to the government inquiry into the 1970s Arkansas real estate venture that President Clinton (then Governor of Arkansas) and Hillary Clinton were partners in.
Legal document in which a person specifies the disposition of his or her property after death.
Physical safeguards to prevent harm to one who is to appear and give testimony in a criminal case.
Persons who give evidence concerning facts relevant to an alleged violation, or testify as to the character of a defendant.
Integration and participation of women in the economic development process; primarily concerns international development.
Programs allowing inmates residing in correctional facilities to leave facility premises regularly for the purpose of working, thereby slowly re-integrating them into the community.
Insurance that provides medical benefits and continued income for employees injured in work-related accidents.
Refers to unskilled, semi-skilled, and skilled nonprofessional workers considered as a class.
